Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: The acquaintance learns a sensitive piece of information about a person that could be used to harm their reputation.
Situation2: They spot a child struggling in the deep end where swimming is restricted.
Story: I was sitting at the edge of the pool, scanning the water as part of my lifeguard shift, when I overheard a group of regulars chatting nearby. One of them, Sarah, leaned over and whispered to me, “Did you hear about Mark? I heard he’s been sneaking in after hours.” I knew the truth—Mark had confided in me that he sometimes stayed late to clear his head, but he wasn’t causing trouble. As an acquaintance, I felt a strong urge to protect his privacy and not fuel any gossip. At the same time, as a lifeguard, I was expected to enforce all safety rules, including after-hours restrictions. Before I could respond, I noticed a small child flailing in the deep end, a spot strictly off-limits to non-swimmers. My mind raced. Should I address the gossip, risking Mark’s trust, or focus on the immediate safety issue, possibly letting the rumor spread unchecked? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something different, and I felt torn, caught between loyalty and duty, unsure which expectation to meet first.
